Graphical abstract Templated synthesis proves to be a facile and cost-efficient method for the preparation of hollow and porous oxygen and hydrogen evolution reaction electrocatalysts. Transition metal phosphides (TMPs) have been regarded as alternative hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) catalysts owing to their comparable activity to those of noble metal-based catalysts. TMPs have been produced in various morphologies, including hollow and porous nanostructures, which are features deemed desirable for electrocatalytic materials. Templated synthesis routes are often responsible for such morphologies. This paper reviews the latest advances and existing challenges in the synthesis of TMP-based OER and HER catalysts through templated methods. A comprehensive review of the structure–property–performance of TMP-based HER and OER catalysts prepared using different templates is presented. The discussion proceeds according to application, first by HER and further divided among the types of templates used—from hard templates, sacrificial templates, and soft templates to the emerging dynamic hydrogen bubble template. OER catalysts are then reviewed and grouped according to their morphology. Finally, prospective research directions for the synthesis of hollow and porous TMP-based catalysts, such as improvements on both activity and stability of TMPs, design of environmentally benign templates and processes, and analysis of the reaction mechanism through advanced material characterization techniques and theoretical calculations, are suggested. Keywords OER HER Transition metal phosphide Templated synthesis Electrocatalysts 1 Introduction 1.1 Renewable H2 production through water electrolysis Renewable energy sources (RES), such as solar, hydropower, geothermal, wind, and biomass, are gaining increasing importance in the global energy mix due to the harmful environmental and health effects of the usage of fossil fuels, as well as the depletion of fossilized reserves [1,2]. However, despite technological advancements, the highly variable and intermittent nature of RES results in the mismatch between the energy demand and supply, thereby necessitating the integration of efficient energy storage and conversion systems [3]. Energy storage is a fundamental concept in the energy economy. Efficient systems allow the full exploitation of the energy produced from renewable sources. In developing new storage materials, their potential impact on the environment and their spontaneity are considered. An ideal storage medium should be able to release stored energy instantaneously without producing harmful by-products. Given these considerations, hydrogen (H2) gas exhibits great potential as an energy storage medium [4]. H2 gas was first artificially synthesized by mixing metals with acids in the 16th century [5]. Although abundant, H2 gas does not naturally occur on Earth as a pure substance. It is commonly found in nature in combination with other elements, such as C and N in fossil fuels and biological materials, or with O in water [6]. Therefore, H2 is typically produced through the decomposition of H-bearing compounds. Currently, approximately 95% of the global annual H2 production can be attributed to steam reforming of natural gas, mostly methane [7]. In steam reforming, the desulfurized natural gas feed is reacted first with steam, producing a mixture of CO and H2, more commonly known as syngas. Supplemental H2 generation happens in the second step, in which syngas is introduced to a shift-converter reactor, where it undergoes an exothermic water shift reaction at 200 to 400 °C. Lastly, purification is performed wherein the diluent CO2 is removed in a scrubbing unit [8]. H2 is often produced through partial oxidation using heavier hydrocarbons. Partial oxidation is similar to steam reforming [9]; however, for this process, the hydrocarbon is made to react with O2 instead of steam, as in Eq. (1). (1) C n H m + n 2 O 2 → n C O + m 2 H 2 Considering the depleting fossil reserves and the production of CO2, H2 production through steam reforming and partial oxidation does not meet the needs of renewable energy storage. Alternatively, H2 can be produced through the hydrolysis of water in an electrolytic cell [8]. Water electrolysis is among the simplest methods employed to produce hydrogen. It is an environmentally benign process, where water is split into H2 and O2 gases through the application of an electrical potential [10,11]. (2) H 2 O l → H 2 ( g ) + 1 2 O 2 ( g ) The reaction in Eq. (2) takes place in an electrolytic cell, which is typically composed of two electrodes (anode and cathode) and an electrolyte. The anode and cathode are where the governing reactions, oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), occur. Meanwhile, the electrolyte facilitates the transfer of charge carriers. Water splitting can occur under different reaction conditions— in aqueous alkaline or acidic electrolytes at low to moderate temperatures, or with solid oxide electrolytes at high temperatures [12]. Depending on the type of electrolyte and the working temperature, water electrolysis cells can be classified as alkaline, proton exchange membrane (PEM), and solid oxide (SOEC) electrolysis cells. Each works around different electrode reactions according to the type of charge transported through the electrolyte [13]. At standard conditions (25 °C, 1 bar), the standard cell voltage (V rev) required for water electrolysis is 1.23 V vs. RHE. At equilibrium, the water-splitting reaction occurs at an infinitely small rate, something that is of no practical interest [12]. In order to produce H2 and O2 at an appropriate speed, V must be significantly larger than V rev. This is to consider the impedance to the current flow during the reaction. The main resistances to current flow are due to the: (i) charge transfer overvoltage at the anode/electrolyte (η a) and cathode/electrolyte (η c) interfaces and (ii) the ohmic drop (R cell) across the electrolyte and other cell components. Considering these, the voltage that should be applied to an electrolysis cell (V cell) should be (3) V cell = V rev + η a i + η c i + i R cell The difference between V cell and V rev is a measure of the efficiency of the electrolyzer system [7,14]. Theoretically, the voltage required to electrolyze water is 1.23 V. However, due to the sluggish OER and HER kinetics, the actual voltage exceeds this value. The losses at the electrode/electrolyte interface must be minimized to improve the efficiency [15]. For such reasons, catalysts are often used in the electrodes to facilitate the charge transfer processes during electrolysis [16]. In addition to slow kinetics, potential drops due to concentration polarization are significant, especially at higher currents, implying the need for electrode materials that allow the efficient transfer of gas bubbles [15,17]. 1.2 Challenges with electrocatalysts for OER and HER Electrocatalysts are thus used to reduce the high overpotentials encountered during OER and HER. A catalyst enhances the rate of a chemical reaction by providing new reaction pathways without undergoing a permanent chemical change [18]. Hence, an electrode material that speeds up a Faradaic reaction without being altered could be considered an electrocatalyst [19]. Electrocatalysis involves the cyclic process of complex formation on a catalytic site and then, product desorption, thereby reverting the site to its original state and rendering the electrode material unchanged [20]. In the case of water electrolysis wherein the reactants are liquid and the products are gas, multiple phases are involved. Hence, the electrocatalysts are considered heterogeneous catalysts, and the reactions usually occur on the surface. Therefore, an ideal catalyst for OER and HER should have an active surface to facilitate the adsorption of the reactants and the desorption of the products. Additionally, it should have high electrical conductivity, good chemical stability, and low intrinsic overpotential ( η ) [20,21]. Electrocatalyst activity is usually measured by the current density attained at a certain value of η or by the η required to reach a certain current density. As a rule of thumb, a good electrocatalyst should reach high current density at a low η [22]. The Sabatier principle states that optimal catalytic activity is achieved when the interaction between the electrode material and the reactants and products is of intermediary strength [23]. That is to say that the catalyst should interact not too weakly with the reactants for the surface reaction to occur and not too strongly with the products for the desorption to happen [24]. The Sabatier principle provides a general qualitative framework for the determination of the optimum heterogeneous catalyst. It usually gives rise to a volcano-like relationship between catalytic performance and bond strength [22,24]. The widely accepted mechanism of HER [25] involves the formation of adsorbed hydrogen (Hads) on the cathode surface (Eq. (4)). (4) H + + e - → H ads This step is followed either by chemical recombination (Eq. (5)) or electrochemical desorption (Eq. (6)). (5) 2 H ads → H 2 (6) H + + e - + H ads → H 2 To select the most suitable electrode materials, it is necessary to identify which of the reactions (Eqs. (4) to (6)) is the rate-determining step (RDS). When the reaction in Eq. (4) is the RDS, electrode surfaces with more edges and cavities will favor the adsorption owing to the higher number of available hydrogen adsorption sites. For this case, the Tafel slope is expected to be around 120 mV dec−1. If either of the recombination (Eq. (5)) or desorption (Eq. (6)) processes is the RDS, surface roughness and perforation could improve the electron transfer and prevent bubbles from growing, which could increase the electrolysis rate. The Tafel slope is expected to be approximately 30 and 40 mV dec−1 if chemical recombination and electrochemical desorption is RDS, respectively [26]. The mechanism of OER mechanism is more complex than that of HER, and the understanding of the OER pathway remains incomplete. Usually, the mechanism depends on the type of the electrode or catalyst being used. Nonetheless, the following is the most generally accepted mechanism for OER in alkaline media: (7) OH ads - ⇄ OH ads + e - (8) OH - + OH ads - ⇄ O ads + H 2 O + e - (9) O ads + O ads ⇄ O 2 One of the charge transfer steps in Eq. (7) to (9) can be the RDS, which can be identified considering the transfer coefficient (α) [27] and the Tafel slope variations. The value of α ranges from 0 to 1; however, it is usually assumed to be equal to 0.5. To achieve exceptional catalytic performance in both HER and OER, it is crucial to modify the catalyst surface structure. This modification facilitates the optimization of catalyst composition and morphology, which in turn exposes catalytically active sites and enhances the utilization of interfacial effects [28]. Commercial water splitting catalysts include rare earth metal catalysts, primarily Pt group metals (PGMs). In previous reports, PGMs have been used in combination with other types of metals, forming mixed noble-metal-based catalysts. Mixed noble-metal-based catalysts for water electrolysis include pH-universal IrW nanodendrites [29], Co single atoms and Pt nanoparticles (NPs) on N-doped carbon matrix [30], Cu0.3Ir0.7O δ with oxygen defects [31], and Ir–Ni and Ir–Co nanowires [32]. These catalysts exhibit optimum H+ and OH− binding energies, higher mass activities compared to those of precious metal catalysts, and potential bifunctionality. However, the stability and performance of these catalysts still need to be improved for their long-term use in electrocatalytic reactions. In particular, in-depth investigations into the electronic double layer (EDL) have revealed the continuous reconstruction of the electrode/electrolyte interface reconstruction during OER. This reconstruction results in the dissolution and oxidation of Ir, ultimately leading to less stable and less active catalyst materials [21,33]. Furthermore, rational design and universal synthesis routes for these alternative materials are also still sought after. Advanced characterization techniques are also needed to determine the exact reaction mechanism during catalysis [34]. Lastly, these mixed noble-metal-based catalysts still contain rare metals, which make the overall water splitting process expensive. Metal oxide catalysts have been used instead of the benchmark catalysts owing to their low cost, diverse orbital characteristics, and highly tunable electronic properties, which include the orbital occupancy of the surface [35], degree of 3d–O 2p orbital hybridization, and filled states near the Fermi level [36]. Transition metal oxides (TMOs) based on Fe, Co, Ni, and Mn have high concentrations of surface defects, which improve their catalytic activities towards OER and HER. Additionally, as observed in Ni-Co oxides, non-conducting transition metal species are transformed into their conductive counterparts during the oxidation reaction in OER, further reducing the resistance of the catalyst to charge migration [21]. Moreover, considering the adsorption energies of various oxide surfaces for OER, NiO, Co3O4, and Mn3O4 exhibit optimized surface adsorption energies and thus, lower OER overpotentials [37]. However, the electrocatalytic activities of TMOs are still not up to par with those of the benchmark Ir- and Ru-based catalysts [38]. Moreover, there is still a minimum value of η due to the constant difference of the absorption energies of HOO* and HO* intermediates. Therefore, in addition to the optimization of the adsorption energy of the intermediates, the surface structure should also be modified to circumvent the limitations of this scaling relation. While suitable for OER catalysis, TMOs exhibit low activities as HER catalysts. Hydrogen forms unreactive hydroxyl species when in contact with the oxygen sites at the surface of TMOs. Moreover, TMO-based electrocatalysts suffer from poor stability due to dissolution and surface reconstruction during long-term cycling [39,40]. As a result, other materials, primarily non-metal catalysts such as chalcogenides [41–44], nitrides [45–47], carbides [48,49], tellurides [50,51], and phosphides [52–56] have been receiving increasing interest as bifunctional OER and HER catalysts [47]. These exhibit promising activity and long-term cycling stability [57,58]. Interest in these non-metal catalysts also arises from their ability as pre-catalysts, where they transform into oxides or oxyhydroxides during OER [59]. Among these catalysts, transition metal phosphides (TMPs) exhibit good stability in acidic and alkaline environments, high activity towards OER and HER, and high conductivity, thereby making them suitable alternatives to state-of-the-art catalysts [60]. 1.3 Transition metal phosphide electrocatalysts Recently, transition metal phosphides (TMPs) with the formula M x P y have been gaining research attention owing to their efficient catalytic activity in key electrochemical reactions. TMPs perform well as water-splitting electrocatalysts owing to their structure, which is similar to that of the hydrogenases often used for the reversible oxidation of H2. Moreover, the negatively charged phosphorus group and the metal site may facilitate the capture of protons and hydrides during acidic electrolysis, respectively [61]. Its smallest structural unit is a triangular prism with P atoms in its interior voids, while the local structure is spherical, exposing more coordinated unsaturated surface atoms and presenting a higher density of active sites [11]. Relative to metal oxides and hydroxides, phosphides exhibit higher conductivity, resulting in their better catalytic performance [60]. In addition to their good catalytic activities, TMPs also exhibit good stability in both acidic and alkaline environments, which come from the properties of their constituent atomic elements. In general, metal-rich, and phosphorus-rich TMPs behave differently in terms of activity and stability. Metal-rich TMPs with stronger M−M bonds exhibit superior electrical conductivities than those of phosphorus-rich TMPs. Moreover, the partial electron transfer between the metal and phosphorus atoms improves the stability of metal-rich TMPs in acidic and alkaline electrolytes. For phosphorus-rich TMPs, the P–P bonds accommodate M+ ions, resulting in the fair stability of the catalyst [60]. Several TMP chemistries have been studied for the electrocatalysis of OER and HER. These chemistries include monometallic (CoP, FeP, NiP, Ni2P, Co2P, MoP) [62–67], bimetallic (NiCoP, FeCoP, and NiFeP) [68–70], and trimetallic (NiCoFeP) phosphides [71]. Less active elements with closer electronegativity to those of transition metals, such as Si, have also been introduced to TMPs to improve catalytic stability [72]. Moreover, electrochemical activity and electrical conductivity of TMPs have been considerably enhanced through the introduction of rare earth metal dopants [73]. Heterostructure engineering, heteroatom doping, strain and defect engineering, phase and facet engineering, and amorphization [74–76] are other techniques in improving catalytic activity. In general, these strategies tend to increase the number of catalytically active sites and improve the electrical and ionic conductivity of the catalyst [77]. Additionally, research on TMP catalysts also include the exploration of various morphological modifications. To date, TMP-based catalysts have been produced in different morphologies [78–82], including but not limited to nanoparticles, nanorods, nanosheets, hollow structures, and core–shell structures. Furthermore, TMPs have been synthesized through a wide array of techniques [60,83–85], such as thermolysis, one-step hydrothermal (and solvothermal) route, electrodeposition–phosphidation method, ultrasound-assisted synthesis method, hydrothermal–phosphidation route, templated synthesis, and pyrolysis. Among these techniques, templated methods are deemed one of the most efficient methods for the preparation of materials with a wide range of sizes [86]. Template-mediated routes offer the advantage of crystal growth control at the nanoscale, yielding nanomaterials with well-defined morphologies. Moreover, they are simple and facile routes for the synthesis of porous solids with highly tunable particle size and shape, features often desired for catalyst materials. Lastly, templated methods are highly repetitive and reproducible, making them preferable to template-free synthesis methods [87]. In general, templated methods are classified as hard, soft, and self (sacrificial)-templated routes. Hard templating methods or nano-casting techniques utilize preformed templates, commonly carbon and silica, to produce highly crystalline and single-crystalline mesoporous products [88,89]. However, there are only a few hard templates available, rendering hard templating synthesis highly specific in terms of material compatibility. On top of that, the method often involves multiple steps, which limits the product yield and makes it tedious and resource-intensive [90]. To circumvent the limitations faced in the hard templating method, soft templating routes are now being used for the preparation of porous products. In this technique, surfactants and polymers are used as structure-directing agents. Soft templating methods involving surfactants may proceed either through the cooperative assembly of inorganic species or the true crystal templating pathway [89]. In contrast to hard templating methods, soft templating routes may be performed in a single step because the synthesis of the template may occur vis-à-vis the coating of the desired product. Finally, self-templated synthesis methods are often employed in the preparation of hollow structures [88,89]. This route commonly involves the preparation of templates and the chemical transformation of the precursors into the hollow structures [90]. Self-templates are used to create the inner cavities of the products and the outer shells of the hollow structures. In general, self-templating methods are more reproducible, facile, and low-cost than hard- and soft-templating routes [90]. Several review articles on TMPs, particularly on their performance as energy storage and conversion materials [91–93], have been previously reported. Even more, most of these review articles summarize the performance of a specific TMP chemistry [47,49], such as CoP, NiCo-based phosphides, and FeP, to name a few. In this review (Scheme 1 ), the recent progress on the templated synthesis of TMP-based catalysts for OER and HER is discussed. By doing so, the suitability of templated routes as synthesis processes for electrocatalytic materials is evaluated. Furthermore, the discussion on previous study findings can be beneficial in the development of materials for next-generation water-splitting systems. Lastly, perspectives on the possible research directions are also discussed in the concluding part of this review. 2 Templated synthesis of TMP-based HER catalysts In this section, the templated synthesis of TMP-based HER catalysts using hard, sacrificial (self), and soft templates is reviewed. First, the usage of Si- and Al-based hard templates is presented. Then, sacrificial templates, mostly based on metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), are discussed. Finally, templated routes using soft templates, which include polyethylene oxide–polypropylene oxide–polyethylene (P123), and polyaniline (PANI), are tackled. 2.1 Hard templates Hard templates, which are often based on inorganic materials, such as SiO2 and aluminum oxide, have been widely used for HER catalyst synthesis [94]. For example, Du et al. reported the template-directed growth of CoP nanotubes (NTs) using anodic aluminum oxide (AAO). In this work, CoP NTs were prepared through the low-temperature phosphidation (300 °C) of a Co salt precursor inside AAO, which was subsequently removed by etching the CoP NTs with dilute HF. For comparison, CoP NPs were prepared through the same synthesis procedure but without the AAO template. CoP NTs (Fig. 1 a) and CoP NPs (Fig. 1b) exhibited similar crystalline structures as reported by similar XRD peaks. (Fig. 1c). However, CoP NTs demonstrated better HER catalytic performance than CoP NPs (Fig. 1d). CoP NTs and NPs recorded an overpotential at 10 mA cm−2 ( η 10 ) equal to 129 and 297 mV, respectively. Additionally, CoP NTs (60 mV dec−1) registered a lower Tafel slope than that of CoP NPs (82 mV dec−1). The better HER activity of CoP NTs can be attributed to the high concentration of catalytically active sites, which was approximately twice that of CoP NPs. The achieved nanotube morphology enabled the exposure of both the internal and external surfaces of the catalyst, thus improving its activity. Moreover, the performance of CoP NTs was well-maintained even after 8 h of stability testing, whereas the current density achieved using CoP NPs decreased by 45% within the same time period. From the results of gas chromatography, the calculated Faradaic yield for H2 production using the CoP NT catalyst was close to 100%. The results of the study demonstrate the immense potential of CoP NTs as an electrocatalyst and a material for other electrochemical applications, such as Li-ion battery electrodes [95]. In another study by Du et al., AAO was used to produce FeP nanorods through a simple solvothermal synthesis followed by phosphidation at 300 °C with Ar purging. FeP nanorods registered η 10 (120 mV) close to that of the previously reported CoP NTs. Considering the calculated Tafel slopes, HER occurred more favorably on the one-dimensional catalyst surface than on the bulk FeP catalyst. Moreover, FeP nanorods demonstrated better stability for 40 h than that of bulk FeP [96]. Overall, these studies revealed the advantage of template-derived electrocatalysts compared to their bulk and nanoparticle counterparts, and the potential of AAO in their synthesis. SiO2 is another commonly used hard template for TMP synthesis. Meng et al. synthesized Fe-doped CoP through a nanocasting strategy using mesoporous SiO2 (SBA-15) and a phosphidation step. After producing the meso-Co1.8Fe0.2O x catalyst, SBA-15 was removed using a hot NaOH solution. Co1.8Fe0.2P catalyst exhibited an ordered mesoporous structure with an average porous pipe width of 8 to 9 nm, which was almost similar to that of the template (10 nm). Type IV N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were recorded, which further confirmed the mesoporous structure of the catalyst. For HER, the value of η 10 was as low as 93.7 mV. Fe tuned the electronic structure of CoP, which consequently improved its catalytic activity. Doping TMPs with a secondary heteroatom induces a partial electron transfer from P to the dopant, conferring a partial negative charge to P. This makes proton adsorption more viable, leading to better electrostatic properties. In terms of the overpotential, meso-Co1.8Fe0.2P performed better than bulk CoFeP and bare SBA-15 owing to the synergism of its ordered mesoporous structure from the template and tuned electronic structure from Fe doping. Meso-Co1.8Fe0.2P also demonstrated excellent bifunctional OER and HER catalytic activities, requiring a low cell potential (1.58 V) to achieve 10 mA cm−2 [98]. In another study, nanosheet-assembled three-dimensional (3D) FeP structures (Fig. 1f) were produced for the first time through the topotactic phosphidation of FeO x nanosheets, which were prepared through a physical vapor infiltration-assisted hard templated route using a ferrocene precursor and SBA-15, as shown in Fig. 1(e). Similar to the work of Meng et al., SBA-15 was removed using NaOH solution. The phosphidation temperature was optimized at 350 °C (FeP x -350). FeP x -350 demonstrated the best performance among the samples tested and exhibited excellent HER catalytic activity over a wide pH range (Fig. 1g). It was found that increasing the phosphidation temperature gradually decreased the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface area of FeP x . Overall, the specific surface area of FeP x fabricated through the templated route was still higher than that of the sample synthesized through a conventional impregnation route. Thus, the SBA-15 template rendered FeP x with a unique three-dimensional morphology, which improved the mass transport properties of the catalyst [97]. Other SiO2-based templates, such as KIT-6, have also been used for the templated synthesis of TMPs. KIT-6 has a cubic cage structure with multidirectional pores (4 to 12 nm) [99]. In comparison to SBA-15, KIT-6 has a 3D porous scaffold composed of regular and ordered surfaces and interconnected interiors [100]. Using this template, Li et al. prepared an ordered, mesoporous WP (WP-Mesop) catalyst with an average pore size of 8 nm. The surface area of WP-Mesop was approximately twice that of a non-mesoporous WP nanocatalyst owing to the confinement effect induced by the KIT-6 template. The catalyst produced through templated synthesis performed better than its nonporous and bulk counterparts; η 10 of WP-Mesop were 175 and 229 mV in acidic and alkaline electrolytes, respectively [101]. SiO2 templates have also been used in the synthesis of catalysts with carbon-based supports, which were reported to improve the performance of the active materials. Ge et al. synthesized MoP on N,P-co-doped 3D graphitic carbon support (3D MoP/NPG) through in situ reduction and phosphidation using SiO2 as the hard template [102]. The precursors were phosphidized at a high temperature (850 °C) to ensure the formation of ordered MoP structures [103]. 3D MoP/NPG, which was composed of monodisperse MoP NPs (average particle size of 5 nm) on the carbon layers, retained the uniformly porous network morphology of the template. Without SiO2, rod-shaped MoP/C was produced. The specific surface area of 3D MoP/NPG (94.5 m2/g) was higher than that of MoP/C (11.4 m2/g), and it registered an η 10 value of 126, 148, and 150 mV in alkaline, acidic, and neutral electrolytes, respectively. Correspondingly, the calculated Tafel slopes were 56, 49, and 102 mV dec−1, which suggest that the desorption of H2 gas dictates the rate of the reaction in extreme pH conditions. The charge transfer resistance of MoP/NPG (13.3 Ω) was considerably lower than that of MoP/C (19.8 Ω), thereby proving the success of the methodology employed for the design of active electrocatalysts [102]. Most studies utilizing hard templates have studied the effect of phosphidation temperature and duration. Thus far, hard templates have produced HER catalysts with porous nanotube and nanosheet morphologies. These morphologies result in promising HER activities in alkaline, acidic, and even neutral media. However, despite its ability to yield catalysts with morphologies analogous to it, a hard template presents itself as a drawback as it requires a template removal step. 2.2 Sacrificial or self-templates Self-templating or endo-templating methods are classified under hard templating routes. However, for this type, the template removal step is avoided by using a material that simultaneously acts as the precursor and template of the desired catalyst. MOFs are among the most explored self-templates owing to their good morphology, degree of crystallinity, electrical and electrochemical properties, and high porosity. [104]. For HER electrocatalysis, MOFs are used either directly as catalysts or indirectly as precursors for MOF-based composites or MOF–graphene hybrids [104]. During synthesis, the organic ligands in MOFs form a carbon matrix. At the same time, the inorganic metal precursors diffuse inside the matrix, thereby forming in situ templates for the porous active material. Furthermore, the metal ions may exfoliate the carbon matrix and etch the micropores during high-temperature treatments, leading to the exposure of more active sites in the catalysts. As such, self-templated routes that utilize MOFs offer the ease of controlling the morphology and structure of the catalysts through the careful design of the metal–organic precursors [105]. Among different MOFs, zeolitic imidazole frameworks (ZIFs) have been widely used as templates for the synthesis of electrocatalysts, supercapacitors, photocatalysts, and absorption materials owing to their high porosity [106]. In particular, ZIF-67, which is composed of a Co2+ ion metal center and 2-methylimidazolate anion ligands, is commonly used for the preparation of HER catalysts [107–110]. ZIF-67 has a cubic crystal structure with micropores that are approximately 0.34 nm. This MOF can be produced through solvothermal synthesis at high temperatures using organic solvents or through hydrothermal synthesis at room temperature [111]. Through the method shown in Fig. 2 (a), Li et al. produced Ni-doped CoP using ZIF-67 as a sacrificial template and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O as the metal precursor. Layered double hydroxides (LDHs) were also added to form a hollow quasi-polyhedron morphology (Fig. 2b) with a large surface area. For comparison, hollow CoP polyhedrons were also synthesized using the same template but with Co3O4 as the precursor. Adsorption and desorption isotherms and Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) pore size distribution curves reveal the presence of mesopores (2 to 8 nm) and macropores (∼50 nm) in the synthesized NiCoP catalyst. Herein, the optimum Ni/Co ratio and phosphidation temperature were found to be 1:2.5 and 300 °C (NiCoP-2.5–300), respectively. NiCoP-2.5–300, with an η 10 of 124 mV and Tafel slope of 42 mV dec−1 under alkaline conditions, performed considerably better than the hollow CoP polyhedrons (Fig. 2c). Additionally, NiCoP-2.5–300 exhibited good stability and durability even after 1000 electrochemical cycles [108]. In another study [109], CoP was doped with Ce through a two-step templated method involving solvothermal treatment and low-temperature phosphidation step at 250 °C under an Ar/H2 environment. Ce-doped CoP exhibited rough surfaces and uniform polyhedral morphology with an approximate diameter of 800 nm. The sacrificial ZIF-67 template conferred the catalyst with a high surface area and small micropore size (0.4–0.6 nm). Fig. 2(d) reveals the homogenous dispersion of Co (Fig. 2e), P (Fig. 2f), and Ce (Fig. 2g) in the Ce-doped Co catalyst. Considering the electrochemical performance and ECSA of the prepared Ce-doped CoP catalysts, the optimum Ce/Co ratio was 1:1 (Ce-1-CoP). Ce-1-CoP registered η 10 and Tafel slope equal to 144 mV and 70 mV dec−1 in 1 M KOH. DFT calculations revealed that Ce doping reduced the surface hydrogen binding energy (Fig. 2h), which consequently improved the catalytic activity of CoP (Fig. 2i). Ce-1-CoP also exhibited good activity towards OER catalysis. When used as the cathode and anode, Ce-1-CoP required only a cell potential of 1.65 V to achieve 10 mA cm−2. Its performance remained stable even after 15 h of operation [109]. Sacrificial templating methods also produce heterostructured HER catalysts. Heterostructures are composed of interfaces of chemically or physically bonded solid-state materials. They may be formed using a combination of either two or more active materials, including TMPs, transition metal nitrides, transition metal carbides, doped carbon, and metals, or of an active material with a non-active material, such as carbonaceous supports, organic macromolecules, and metal hydroxides [113]. On one hand, non-active materials like graphene oxide can anchor metal atoms into their surface by converting oxygen-containing groups to oxygen-metal bonds, thereby improving the contact and conductivity of the resulting catalyst [114]. On the other hand, the addition of active materials may add structural defects that consequently improve electrochemical performance, as observed by Zhang et al. [110] In their work, a heterostructured CoP/CoMoP layered catalyst was synthesized through a templated route using ZIF-67 (Fig. 2j). Initially, CoMo oxide precursors were prepared through dissolution–regrowth processes that occurred during hydrothermal treatment. After the two-step phosphidation of these precursors at 350 and 600 °C under N2 purging, CoP/CoMoP nanocages were obtained. The catalyst produced at a Mo/Co ratio of 5 (CoP-5-CoMoP) exhibited the best performance under alkaline conditions with a low η 10 of 72 mV and a Tafel slope of 60.3 mV dec−1. CoP-5-CoMoP also exhibited excellent HER electrocatalytic activities in H2SO4 and phosphate-buffered saline electrolytes with η 10 equal to 44 and 151 mV, respectively. The promising electrochemical performance of CoP-5-CoMoP can be attributed to the uniform dispersion of the Co, Mo, and P atoms (Fig. 2k−m), and to the presence of lattice defects in the heterostructure, which were all achieved through the employed sacrificial templated route. DFT calculations (Fig. 2n, o) report the upward shift in the total density of states of the CoP-5-CoMoP lattice and thermoneutral free energy changes of the P and Co sites, thus making them suitable active sites for HER. The CoP-5-CoMoP catalyst exhibited high porosity, small pore size (4 nm), and high specific surface area, which was approximately thrice that of CoP, thereby resulting in its improved HER performance. Lastly, the charge transfer resistance of the heterostructured CoP-5-CoMoP (32 Ω) catalyst was lower than that of the pure phase, hollow CoP NPs (220 Ω) [110]. Zhou et al. also produced a heterostructure using MOFs. In their work, NiCoP was encapsulated with graphitized carbon to achieve pH insensitive HER activity. The MOF nanosheet template used in the study contained the NiCl2·6H2O and CoCl2·6H2O metal precursors. The MOF nanosheet array was then phosphidized using NaH2PO2 and further heated to obtain the encapsulated catalyst on graphitized carbon. The obtained catalyst (Fig. 2p) exhibited highly promising electrochemical performance, with a η 10 and Tafel slope of 46.3 mV and 44.1 mV dec−1, respectively. Its bimetallic nature positively affected the electronic structure of the catalyst. The obtained experimental data was further supported by DFT calculations, which revealed the optimized hydrogen adsorption (Fig. 2q) and water molecule adsorption (Fig. 2r) on the surface of the encapsulated catalyst, as well as the shift of the d-band centers of the metal atoms. The shift in the d-band centers of the metal atoms resulted in improved conductivity and facilitated stronger binding between the adsorbates of reaction intermediates and the catalyst surface. Meanwhile, the graphitized carbon effectively prevented the catalyst agglomeration and loss of active sites, improving catalyst durability. This was confirmed by electrochemical testing and Raman spectroscopy characterization performed before and after long-term testing. In summary, this study effectively combined two techniques to enhance electrocatalyst performance: the bimetallic nature of the TMP improved the electronic structure, while the heterostructure formation with the carbon support increased conductivity [112]. Other carbon-based materials, such as metal-doped carbon frameworks, can also be used in the heterostructure engineering involving TMPs. In a recent study, Li et al. used a porous single-atomic Co-doped carbon framework in designing an active and stable Mo–CoP electrocatalyst for HER. Therein, a carbon nitride (C3N4) self-template was produced through the calcination of urea (CH4N2O). To synthesize the Mo-CoP/Co-N-C catalyst, the C3N4 template was then mixed with the metal and phosphide precursors, namely CoCl2·6H2O, (NH4)2MoO4, and NH4H2PO4. To determine the effect of Mo-doping on the catalyst, CoP/Co-N-C and Co-N-C were also prepared. XRD, SEM, TEM, and STEM-EDS results showed that Mo was successfully introduced into the CoP structure. Moreover, the binding energy of the Co 2p peaks shifted to higher values as Mo was doped into the catalyst. Raman spectroscopy revealed that defects were introduced upon the addition of Mo to the CoP/Co-N-C structure. More importantly, Mo-CoP/Co-N-C exhibited the highest BET surface area among the samples tested. All these structural and morphological modifications led to impressive catalytic activity. Particularly, the Mo-CoP/Co-N-C catalyst only required an overpotential of 45 and 201 mV to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2 in alkaline HER and OER operations, respectively. The overpotential to reach a high current density of 500 mA cm−2 was even smaller for the Mo-CoP/Co-N-C catalyst when compared to that of the benchmark Pt/C catalyst. Furthermore, the low charge transfer resistance (8 Ω) and high TOF (0.741 s−1) imply the improvement of the rates of electron transfer processes and reactions, respectively. Lastly, the Mo-CoP/Co-N-C catalyst exhibited the best stability, retaining up to 98% of the initial current density even after 24 h of operation in alkaline OER and HER [115]. Prussian blue analogues (PBAs) is another class of Co-based MOFs used for the synthesis of electrochemical materials. PBAs have a cubic structure and exhibit large surface area, high porosity, controllable composition, and highly tunable functionality. For example, Tan et al. employed CoFe PBA nanocubes as the self-template in synthesizing hollow CoFeP/CoP catalysts. The PBA MOFs were prepared using Co(NO3)2·6H2O, PVP, Na3C6H5O7·2H2O, and K3Fe(CN)6. Hollow CoFeP/CoP catalysts were then produced after phosphorization for 2 h under N2 environment at varying temperatures. CoP and FeP peaks were observed in the XRD pattern of the product. HRTEM imaging revealed the lattice spacing of CoP and FeP. Lastly, the homogeneous distribution of Co, Fe, and P atoms was observed through EDS mapping. These findings confirm the successful doping of Fe onto the CoP catalysts. The catalyst produced at 400 °C (CoFeP/CoP-400) registered the lowest η 10 (78 mV). The stability of the catalyst was also tested. Chronoamperometry results revealed that CoFeP/CoP maintained excellent performance even after 20 h of operation. Additionally, only minimal changes were observed in the LSV recorded before and after 3000 electrochemical cycles, confirming the robust stability of CoFeP/CoP-400 [116]. Other than CoP, TMPs can also be prepared using ZIF-based MOFs by modifying the metal center. For example, Ni2P was synthesized by He et al. on a carbon core–shell support using a Ni ZIF-67 template, which contained Ni2+ metal cation centers instead of Co2+ [107]. Ni2P is regarded as one of the best HER catalysts owing to its structure’s similarity with the H2-evolving [NiFe] hydrogenase enzyme catalyst. In another study, Ni2P was produced using another widely used ZIF-based template (ZIF-8). Instead of Co2+ centers as in ZIF-67, ZIF-8 contains Zn2+ cation centers [117]. Wang et al. produced hollow Ni2P catalysts on (Ni2P@C) carbon support using a Ni(OH)2@resorcinol formaldehyde (RF) template derived from a RF-coated ZIF-8 precursor (ZIF-8@RF). Ni2P@C was obtained through the phosphidation of Ni(OH)2@RF at varying temperatures for 2 h in an Ar gas environment using NaH2PO2·H2O. In addition to phosphide formation, carbonization also occurred during phosphidation owing to the presence of the organic RF coating. The resulting amorphous carbon matrix served as a protective layer that helped the catalyst retain the rhombohedral shape of ZIF-8. The results of the work of Wang et al. corresponded well to those of He et al., which revealed that the HER activity of Ni2P@C improved as the phosphidation temperature was increased up until a certain point. Herein, the optimum temperature was 350 °C, which is close to the earlier reported value (400 °C). The best performing Ni2P@C registered a low η 10 (48 mV), high turnover frequency (0.84 s−1), fair Tafel slope (83.5 mV dec−1), low charge transfer resistance (6.74 Ω), and excellent stability even after 30 h of operation. The decrease in charge transfer resistance and improvement in stability were attributed to the synergy of the Ni2P NPs with the carbonaceous support. Meanwhile, the good HER activity of the catalyst was a result of the porous morphology (average pore diameter of 8.69 nm). The hydrogen adsorption free energy of Ni2P-350 from DFT calculations was also sufficient (–0.24 eV) to make hydrogen adsorption spontaneous. Moreover, the Ni2P@C hybrid showed bifunctionality with a low OER η 10 of 326 mV. All tests were conducted in 1 M KOH electrolyte [118]. Ni2P can also be produced using MOFs other than ZIF-based templates. For example, Yan et al. synthesized single-phase, hierarchically porous Ni2P polyhedrons using Ni-MOF-74. MOF-74 is composed of divalent metal cation centers and 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid ligands. It has a honeycomb structure with a pore size of 12 nm [119]. Ni2P polyhedrons were prepared by phosphidizing Ni-MOF-74 using NaH2PO2·H2O at 275 °C under an Ar atmosphere for 2 h (Ni2P Ps-2) and 3 h (Ni2P Ps-3). For comparison, Ni2P NPs were also obtained using Ni(C2H3O2)2 •4H2O as the Ni source. Ni2P Ps-3 was purely Ni2P while Ni2P Ps-2 was composed of both unreacted Ni-MOF-74 and Ni2P phases. The morphology of Ni-MOF-74 was well maintained after the phosphidation step, suggesting that in situ transformation of the material occurred during heating. During phosphidation, the generated PH3 from the decomposition of NaH2PO2·H2O diffused and reduced the metal center of the MOF. The Ni centers, which were originally linked to O atoms, coordinated with P atoms, forming the highly porous Ni2P clusters. Moreover, the surface of the original polyhedral coarsened and became rougher after phosphidation. As a result, the specific surface area of Ni2P Ps-3 (175 m2g−1) was higher than that of Ni2P particles produced using Ni(C2H3O2)2·4H2O (18.7 m2/g), thus demonstrating the huge advantage of using a MOF template over a nonporous precursor. Ni2P Ps-3 polyhedrons registered comparable performance to that of a standard Pt/C catalyst, with η 10 , Tafel slope, and charge transfer resistance as low as 158 mV, 73 mV dec−1, and 42 Ω, respectively. Regardless of the electrolyte used, the pure Ni2P Ps-3 catalyst also exhibited the best stability among the synthesized catalysts; the value of η (150 mV) remained low even after 20 h of operation at 10 mA cm−2. Overall, the templated synthesis of Ni2P Ps-3 using Ni-MOF-74 conferred the catalyst hierarchical pore structure, abundant sites for charge transfer processes, accessible contact area for electrolyte diffusion, and consequently, good activity towards HER [120]. NENU-5, which is a MOF first fabricated by the Northeast Normal University, has also been used for the synthesis of oxide, sulfide, and phosphide-based HER electrocatalysts owing to its porous morphology and high surface area. NENU-5 is composed of Cu2+ metal cation center and ligands such as C6H3(CO2H)3, (NH4)3PMo12O40, and H3PW12O40. Sun et al. employed NENU-5 as a sacrificial template to produce different types of porous catalysts, namely MoWO2 NPs, MoWS2 nanosheets, MoWP NPs, and MoWOSP@C composite catalysts. First, the thermolysis of NENU-5 yielded MoWO@C nanooctahedrons. These precursors were then transformed to MoWOS@C after the addition of thioacetamide and a sulfurization step at 200 °C. Finally, MoWOS@C was converted to MoWOSP@C after phosphidation. Both the sulfurization and phosphidation durations had significant effects on the properties of the synthesized catalyst. The performance deteriorated as sulfurization and phosphidation were performed longer than 6 and 2 h, respectively. The best performing MoWOSP@C catalyst registered an η 10 of 118 mV and a Tafel slope of 74.1 mV dec−1. MoWOSP@C also had the lowest charge transfer resistance (858 Ω) among the prepared catalysts, verifying the superior conductivity of phosphides over sulfides. Overall, the study demonstrated the benefits of combining oxide and sulfide catalysts with phosphides for HER applications. Additionally, the use of NENU-5 resulted in a MoWOSP@C catalyst hybrid with a hollow carbon matrix, which avoided the agglomeration of the catalyst and improved stability during electrochemical testing. As in the other catalysts reported thus far, the best-performing catalyst exhibited good activity owing to its porous morphology, abundant electron transport channels, and high surface area [121]. Studies involving sacrificial templates have mainly dealt with the optimization of phosphidation temperature and transition metal ratio. The effect of incorporating multiple transition metals in a catalyst was further studied using surface and electronic properties from DFT calculations. Given the various templates existing in literature, choosing the right precursors and synthesis method for the sacrificial template is a crucial step in creating HER catalysts. Overall, self-templates enable accurate and replicable synthesis of highly active HER catalysts with targeted morphologies. Sacrificial templates also allow the fabrication of heterostructures to improve both the apparent and inherent electronic properties of HER catalyst materials. 2.3 Soft self-templates In addition to hard templates, soft templates have also been used to create porous electrocatalysts. Catalyst synthesis using soft templates can be carried out through micelle assembly and lyotropic liquid crystal (LLC) templating approaches [122]. However, only micelle-forming solutions will be discussed here primarily because of the limitations of LLCs in practical experiments arising from the usage of viscous solutions. Here, polyethylene oxide–polypropylene oxide–polyethyleneoxide (P123) and polyaniline (PANI) as soft templates for TMP synthesis are reviewed. Geng et al. prepared hole-rich CoP nanosheets using the soft template P123, a nonionic triblock copolymer (pluronic). The study was inspired by the same group’s previous results from DFT calculations, which revealed that the addition of holes lowered the Gibb’s free energy of H adsorption (ΔG H*) both on the Co and P atoms in CoP. Without P123, only nanorod arrays were formed. As such, P123 drove the anisotropic 2D growth of the nanosheets through the self-assembly of the nanorods. The porous morphology of the precursor was well-preserved even after calcination and phosphidation. The resulting hole-rich CoP nanosheets exhibited the best HER activity among the CoP-based catalysts tested. The values of η 10 in acidic and alkaline media were 84 and 94 mV, respectively. HER on the hole-rich CoP nanosheets followed the Volmer–Heyrovsky pathway with a Tafel slope of 61 mV dec−1. The charge transfer resistance in a H2SO4 electrolyte decreased in the order: 1765 Ω (CoP NPs) > 116 Ω (CoP nanorods) > 31 Ω (CoP nanosheets). On the other hand, the charge transfer resistance in alkaline environment decreased from 570 to 28 Ω for CoP NPs and CoP nanosheets, respectively. Moreover, the porous hole-rich CoP nanosheets registered steeper LSV curves compared to that of a benchmark Pt/C catalyst in 1 M KOH, indicating faster kinetics [123]. In another study, Huang et al. synthesized mesoporous Fe-doped CoP (meso-Fe x Co1- x P) following the methodology shown in Fig. 3 (a). With P123 as the soft template, Meso-Fe x Co1- x P (Fig. 3b) was produced after a low temperature phosphidation step. As the Fe/Co ratio in the catalyst was increased, the overpotential and Tafel slope decreased; the best HER activity was recorded with the meso-Fe0.3Co0.7P sample. Under alkaline conditions, the catalyst registered a Tafel slope and an η 10 of 44 mV dec−1 and 103 mV, respectively, which are close to the values recorded using Pt/C. Meso-Fe0.3Co0.7P also showed good performance in acidic electrolyte (Fig. 3c and d) with an η 10 of 89 mV. The good electrochemical performance of meso-Fe0.3Co0.7P can be attributed to its high surface area (147.5 m2g−1) and small pore size (6–9 nm). Furthermore, DFT calculations and projected density of states (PDOS) analysis (Fig. 3e and f) revealed that Fe doping moved the d-band center and optimized Δ G H ∗ , hence improving the HER activity of CoP [124]. Substantially, P123 as soft templates yield catalysts with performances comparable to Pt/C. PANI has also been used as a soft template for the preparation of porous catalysts. PANI is an organic conductive polymer with good chemical stability and mechanical flexibility. The presence of lone pair electrons in the N atoms of the PANI molecules makes this soft template coordinate with metal ions easily. In a study by Li et al., carbon-coated Co2P (Co2P@C) catalyst was synthesized through high-temperature calcination and phosphidation using PANI as the N and C sources of the catalyst, which effectively reduced the costs for raw materials. The good coordination between Co2+ ions and PANI in the Co2+/PANI precursor solution was confirmed through UV–vis spectrometry. After mixing, the peaks corresponding to PANI disappeared, whereas those attributed to Co2+ demonstrated a red shift. This, along with the observed color changes upon mixing, revealed that PANI underwent structural changes and successfully coordinated with the Co2+ ions. Then, spherical Co2P@C catalyst with nonuniform morphology (Fig. 3g) was produced after the one-step calcination/phosphidation at 950 °C. BET measurements and N2 adsorption isotherms reveal the large surface area (225.5 m2g−1) and good average porosity (2.44 nm) of the catalyst. The catalyst yielded a 192 mV η 10 and a 93 mV dec−1 Tafel slope under an acidic environment. Co2P@C also demonstrated good stability, exhibiting minimal changes in its morphology and performance even after 2000 cycles of electrochemical testing [125]. The studies reviewed thus far confirm that templated methods are effective in producing TMP-based catalysts with considerably good activity and stability. On one hand, traditional hard templating methods require the removal of the template used, resulting in added costs and longer synthesis processes. On the other hand, soft templating methods often involve multi-step processes that require the use of expensive precursors and high phosphidation/calcination temperatures. As such, developing facile and low-cost synthesis methods is beneficial for the preparation of highly active, porous TMP-based catalysts. Moreso, templated synthesis routes that yield catalysts with uniform morphology and better stability, and allow the flexible adjustment of pore size, pore size distribution, and other morphological properties, are also sought after. 2.4 Dynamic hydrogen bubble template The dynamic hydrogen bubble template (DHBT) method is an emerging synthesis technique capable of producing porous 3D architectures without relying on additional organic or inorganic templates [126]. In this route, electrodeposition occurs simultaneously with HER; the H2 bubbles produced during HER act as a pore template for the deposition of the material of interest (Fig. 4 a). This technique yields porous catalysts with pore sizes that can be varied by changing the synthesis parameters, such as electrodeposition duration, electrodeposition potential, and electrolyte composition [127]. Despite being a relatively new synthesis technique, DHBT has been used to produce materials for sensing and catalytic applications. Specifically, DHBT synthesis has been employed to prepare transition metal catalysts, such as Ni and Cu [128]. DHBT has also been gaining attention in TMP synthesis. In particular, Song et al. synthesized highly porous NiP electrodes. NiP was electrodeposited onto a Ni plate for 10 s under controlled pH conditions. Owing to the evolution of H2 during the synthesis, NiP was porous with a mean pore size of 2.3 µm. It required η 10 as low as 99 mV. The catalyst even reached higher current densities than Pt/C at η greater than 129 mV. The promising activity of NiP can be attributed to the synergistic effect between its good porosity and 3D architecture. The catalyst was also found to be bifunctional with good activity and stability towards OER [132]. DHBT has also been used to prepare heterostructure electrodes, particularly Ni phosphide/sulfide microspheres on Ni foam (NiPS/NF). Synthesis proceeded first with DHBT performed at –1 A cm−2 for 10 min, followed by phosphidation at 400 °C for 2 h, and finally with sulfurization at 300 °C for 3 h under N2 flow. Prior to sulfurization, the NiP catalyst was oxidized using cyclic voltammetry. Ni2P and NiS2 phases were present in the catalyst, as confirmed by XRD peaks and TEM lattice fringes corresponding to Ni2P (111) and NiS2 (220) phases. The catalyst performed well both in HER and OER, requiring η as low as 169 and 320 mV, respectively. Chronopotentiometry tests also validated the catalyst’s stability, showing unchanged performance at high current densities for 48 h in a three-electrode set-up and up to 60 h for full-cell testing. Interestingly, the NiPS/NF catalyst also performed well even with alkaline seawater as the electrolyte, thus proving its potential use in the direct electrolysis of seawater. Actual performance in full-cell seawater electrolysis was also evaluated; the NiPS/NF catalyst only required 1.66 V to reach 100 mA during full cell operation. Moreover, a high faradaic efficiency of 96.2 % was calculated by getting the amount of gas produced during full-cell testing [133]. Aside from bifunctional catalysts, pH-insensitive TMP catalysts have also been synthesized through DHBT. Hou et al. produced coralline-like CoP3 on a Cu-D electrode (CoP3@Cu/Cu) that demonstrated good performance under acidic and alkaline conditions. The morphology attained through DHBT synthesis endowed CoP3@Cu/Cu with abundant exposed active sites that facilitated mass transport. Under an acidic medium, the catalyst registered η 10 equal to 101 mV and a Tafel slope of 44 mV dec−1. The catalyst also maintained good performance even after 25 h of operation [134]. In addition to heterostructure engineering, heteroatom doping as a technique for improving catalytic activity of water splitting catalysts has also been explored with DHBT. It should be noted that for the effective upscaling of doping engineering, controlled yet simple synthesis methods are desired [135]. DHBT can thus bridge this gap. As in the recent work of Asnavandi et al., a pH-insensitive NiCuP catalyst on Ni mesh was synthesized through DHBT followed by phosphidation at 500 °C under Ar environment. NiCuP (Ni/Cu ratio = 7:3) exhibited a hierarchical, porous structure with pore diameters ranging from 2 to 50 µm. The ECSA of the porous catalyst was considerably larger (32 cm2) than that of the nonporous NiCuP (0.51 cm2), effectively proving the advantage of the DHBT method. Interestingly, this study found that Cu was critical in the formation of pores; NiP was less porous than CuP and NiCuP (Fig. 4b–d). The η 10 recorded using NiCuP under acidic, alkaline, and neutral media were 226, 175, and 250 mV, respectively (Fig. 4e and f) [130]. In another study, Ji et al. prepared NiCoP nanorods through the DHBT method. Unlike in the work of Asnavandi et al., the synthesis of the bimetallic NiCoP involved three steps, namely, preparation of Ni porous coil template through electrodeposition, doping Ni coils with Co, and phosphidation at 300 °C. The resulting NiCoP had a porous and thorn-like morphology. The catalyst had large (7 µm wide) and small (less than 1 µm) pores, with interconnected networks with a length and diameter of 4 to 8 µm and 70 nm, respectively (Fig. 4g and h). The hierarchical porosity facilitated electron transport and electrolyte penetration in the catalyst. The synergism between the exposure of catalytic active sites and the presence of P improved the activity of the catalyst. Electrochemical tests were also carried out to compare the porous NiCoP catalyst with nonporous NiCoP on different substrates, and NiCo2O4 (Fig. 4i and j). NiCoP registered a 61 mV overpotential at 10 mA cm−2 and maintained a high current density (20 mA cm−2) even after 200 h of electrochemical cycling. The stability of the catalyst improved owing to the good adhesion of the catalyst to the Ni substrate because of the electrodeposition method. In addition, the structure produced through DHBT avoided the agglomeration of the nanomaterials during the electrochemical cycling [131]. While most studies still employ a phosphidation step after electrodeposition, some have applied DHBT the method as a one-pot synthesis route for TMP-based catalysts. Park et al. prepared CuCoP electrodes through a one-step, low-temperature DHBT synthesis procedure. The electrodeposition electrolyte contained the metal precursors and phosphorus source (NaH2PO2), which yielded a CuCoP catalyst foam with a dendritic and porous structure. Phosphidation increased the electrochemically active surface area of Cu–Co. The concentration of the P source in the electrodeposition solution was found to be significant. Increasing the concentration of the P source increased the size of the evolved H2 bubbles and the catalyst pores (Fig. 4k–n); the pore size of the 3D dendritic CuCoP ranged from 5 to 10 µm. CuCoP performed well in alkaline media, registering a lower η 10 value (138 mV) (Fig. 4j) compared to those of previously reported catalysts in literature, Cu3P–CoP on carbon cloth (208 mV) [136] and CuCoP on Cu foil (231 mV) [137]. Moreover, its Tafel slope (48 mV dec−1) was nearly similar to that of Pt/C, proving its improved kinetics. The catalyst foam also showed good stability even after 6 h of electrochemical cycling. Overall, this work showed that the morphological, and consequently, the electrochemical properties of catalysts, can be tuned simply by altering the set parameters during DHBT synthesis [129]. As exhibited by these studies, DHBT synthesis is a promising route for the preparation of HER catalysts as it yields materials with hierarchical porosity, a morphology proven to improve electrocatalyst activity. Additionally, the parameters employed in this method can be easily varied to improve the morphology further and consequently, the electrochemical performance of the catalyst. However, considerable work to limit the pore size and achieve uniform pore size distribution of the produced catalysts should be performed. In summary of this section, templated synthesis routes for HER electrocatalysts yield TMP-based catalysts with porous, hollow, and/or nanostructures leading to good activity and stability. Traditional hard templating methods provide the benefit of producing HER-active catalysts with morphologies similar to the template used. This benefit, however, also limits this synthesis method; morphology of catalysts derived from hard templates are restricted to the characteristics of currently available hard templates. Another limitation of hard templates is that it results in additional costs and longer synthesis times due to the added removal of the template used. This barrier can be bypassed with the use of self or sacrificial templates, which yield hollow catalysts with outer morphologies analogous to the MOF used. Additionally, soft templates are also viable alternatives to curb the problem of template removal. However, these two methods usually involve expensive precursors and high phosphidation/calcination temperatures. Thus, DHBT synthesis serves as a promising solution to the problems faced by hard, sacrificial, and soft templated synthesis methods. However, morphology control, especially if one-pot synthesis is desired, are yet to be refined to make DHBT advantageous against other templated synthesis methods. Moreover, studies on templated synthesis methods still fall short in producing bifunctional catalysts, as well as highly stable catalysts that can withstand more hours of operation with unchanged activity. 3 Templated synthesis of TMP-based OER catalysts TMPs have also been used to catalyze OER. TMP-based OER catalysts exhibit high-cost efficiencies and desirable physicochemical properties [138–140]. However, despite these favorable properties, the OER activity and stability of TMPs are still not up to par with the standards required to meet the demands of industrial water electrolysis [141]. In general, the intrinsic OER activity of tranon metal-based catalysts may be tuned by controlling their morphology, structure, and chemical composition [142,143]. Through morphological engineering, the specific surface area and the accessibility of the catalytic active sites may be optimized, which in turn may considerably improve the mass transport properties and charge transfer capacity of the catalyst [144]. Recently, hollow TMP nanostructures have been deemed as promising OER catalysts owing to their high specific surface area, abundant electrochemically active sites, short diffusion path lengths, robust morphology, and fast ion/electron transfer capabilities. Hollow TMP nanostructures have been prepared through different methods, such as hydrothermal routes, thermolysis, and self-templated processes. For example, Liu et al. synthesized hollow, monodisperse FeCoP spheres through a multi-step process involving the hydrothermal synthesis of a FeCo metal–organic complex (MOC) precursor at 150 °C, annealing of the organic ligands of FeCo MOC at 500 °C in an Ar gas environment, and phosphidation using NaH2PO2 [145]. More often, hydrothermal synthesis involves multiple steps. In this case, utilizing more facile and simpler methods for the preparation of hollow nanostructures is desired. Thermolysis is a low-cost approach for the synthesis of hollow TMP nanostructures. The method, which may be done in the solid or liquid phase, involves the chemical decomposition of the precursors through the application of heat [146]. For example, Zhang et al. synthesized bulk and supported hollow TMPs such as Ni2P and FeP spheres through the thermal reduction of metal pyrophosphate precursors using H2 gas. With the appropriate choice of metal pyrophosphate precursors, bi- and trimetallic TMPs may be prepared easily through thermal reduction. In addition to hollow nanostructures with high specific surface areas and abundant concentrations of active sites, high purity is also achieved for TMP catalysts synthesized through thermolysis [147]. While thermolysis proves to be a facile route for the preparation of hollow and high-purity TMPs, the utilization of high-cost precursors and toxic phosphorus sources in this method necessitates the search for facile, low-cost, and safe TMP synthesis [148,149]. For this reason, templated methods have been employed in recent years, owing to their simpler procedures and independence on toxic precursors. In this section, the performance of TMP-based OER catalysts synthesized through templated methods is reviewed. Relative to those in HER catalysis research, fewer reports on the templated synthesis of TMP-based OER catalysts have been previously published. As such, instead of dividing the section into the different templates used as in Section 2, the current discussion will focus on the preparation of TMP-based OER catalysts with different morphologies (hollow, hierarchical 3D structures, 2D structures, and porous (1D and 2D) morphologies), and compositions (mono-, bi-, and tri-metallic TMPs) through templated synthesis methods. 3.1 Hierarchical hollow nanostructures Hollow nanostructures that take the form of nanoboxes, nanorods, nanoplates, and nanospheres will be discussed in this subsection. Yan et al. prepared hierarchical CoP hollow nanoboxes (NBs) through a templated route using a PBA-based MOF with a general formula of M x [M′ y (CN)6] z ·H2O (where M/M′ = Fe, Co, Ni, Cu) [150]. In this work, the Co-based PBA (Co3[Co(CN)6]2) precursor was synthesized first using Co(CH3COO)2 · 4H2O, C6H5O7Na3·2H2O, and K3[Co(CN)6]. CoP NBs were produced after the phosphidation of the Co3[Co(CN)6]2 at 300 °C for 2 h under N2 purging. NaH2PO2·H2O was then used as the P source, and the Co:P molar ratio was fixed at 1:10. Fig. 5 (a) shows the schematic of the formation mechanism of the hollow CoP NBs. CO2 and N x O y gases evolved during thermal decomposition formed vacancies. During the initial stages of thermal oxidation, a thin shell was formed on the surface through the outward diffusion of Co3[Co(CN)6]2. The thin shell shielded the inner Co3[Co(CN)6]2 species from reacting with atmospheric oxygen. As the reaction progressed, voids gradually formed in the porous, thin shell. Eventually, these voids grew owing to the continued evolution of CO2 and N x O y within the cavities, thereby forming the hollow structure. After heat treatment, phosphidation followed to transform the hollow Co3O4 NBs to hollow CoP NBs. (Fig. 5b). For comparison, CoP NPs were also synthesized in this work. The OER activities of the CoP NBs and CoP NPs were characterized through electrochemical polarization measurements in 1.0 M KOH (Fig. 5c). The value of η 10 recorded for CoP NBs was only 240 mV, which is considerably lower than what was recorded using CoP NPs. Furthermore, the Tafel slope of CoP NBs (82.4 mV dec−1) was lower than that of CoP NPs (97.9 mV dec−1), implying faster reaction kinetics on the hollow catalyst surface (Fig. 5d) [150]. CoP NBs registered better OER performance than CoP NPs owing to their higher BET specific surface area (CoP NBs: 112.5 m2g−1, CoP NPs: 59.6 m2g−1) and hierarchical pore structure, which was composed of micro-, meso-, and macropores. Hollow structures with high surface area are desirable for catalytic materials as they provide the electrodes with abundant sites for catalytic activity and electron and mass transport processes. On top of that, hierarchical pore structures promote electrolyte penetration during the electrocatalytic process, further increasing the activity of the catalyst. These findings support the immense potential of templating methods as synthesis routes for OER catalysts. PBA templates can also be prepared with other precursors as proven by Xie et al. in the synthesis of Fe-doped CoP core–shell structures. The PBA template in the study was synthesized with K3Fe(CN)6·3H2O and Co(NO3)2·6H2O precursors. Aging time during the synthesis of PBA was varied to determine its effect on the formed cage structure. CoFe-PBA cage was then transformed into the Fe-CoP cage (Fig. 5e) through phosphidation with NaH2PO2 under Ar atmosphere. Among the synthesized catalysts in the study, the Fe-CoP cage formed from CoFe-PBA aged for 4 h exhibited the lowest η 10 (300 mV) (Fig. 5f) and a stable operation for 12 h of OER testing (Fig. 5g). Aside from confirming the suitability of hollow structures for electrochemical reactions, the PBA template’s formation mechanism was also of great interest to the group. The group discussed how the difference in solubility precipitation constant was the key factor in the formation of the PBA cage. Comparing the morphology of the cages formed under different aging times, the group also reported that longer aging times lead to larger hole space, hence increasing active sites for electrocatalysis [151]. Templated methods may also be employed to produce bimetallic TMPs with improved OER activities. For example, Wang et al. synthesized hollow FeCo bimetallic phosphide electrocatalysts (Fe x Co y P) through a facile templated method using a Fe-based MOF precursor (Fe-MIL-88) [152]. In this work, x and y denote the molar amount of Fe and Co, respectively. Correspondingly, the FeCo MOF precursors used were FeCo2-MIL-88, Fe2Co-MIL-88, and FeCO-MIL-88. Originally, the monometallic Fe-MIL-88 precursor exhibited a hexagonal rod-shaped morphology with a diameter of 100 nm and a length of 1 μm. The incorporation of Co2+ ions into Fe-MIL-88 affected the growth rate and altered the coordination environment around Fe3+ ions and H2BDC ligands, which subsequently affected the size of the rod-like structures. After the phosphidation step at 350 °C for 3 h under an N2 gas environment, no considerable changes in the size and shape of the FeP and Fe x Co y P rods were observed relative to those of their precursors, Fe-MIL-88 and Fe x Co y -MIL-88, respectively. However, the surfaces of the phosphides were considerably rougher than those of the MOF precursors. Further morphological characterization showed that the phosphide nanorods were composed of NPs. Interestingly, in addition to the spindle-like characteristics, FeCo2P exhibited a well-defined hollow structure. Considering the changes in the morphology of the phosphides, Fig. 6 (a) shows the proposed formation mechanism of the Fe x Co y P electrocatalysts. First, the Fe x Co y -MIL-88 precursors were produced through the self-assembly of the Fe3+ and Co2+ metal ion centers and H2BDC ligands in DMA. Similar to the work of Yan et al. on the formation of hierarchical hollow CoP NBs, the hollow structure of the FeCo2P (Fig. 6b and c) was produced through the outward diffusion of the inner metal ions. This hollow structure was not observed when Fe3+ ions dominated the reaction owing to the lower reactivity of Fe3+ ions compared to Co2+ ions towards phosphate formation. This is confirmed by the uniform, solid morphology of FeCoP. The electrochemical properties of the bimetallic phosphide catalysts were evaluated in 0.1 M KOH electrolyte. From Fig. 6(d), the hollow-structured FeCo2P (Co/Fe molar ratio = 2:1) catalyst had the steepest LSV curve and the lowest overpotential at 320 mV. The hollow catalyst thus outperformed the monometallic Fe2P and Co2P catalysts, which registered η 10 = 430 and 420 mV, respectively. Furthermore, the lowest Tafel slope (55 mV dec−1) as shown in Fig. 6(e), and charge transfer resistance (21 Ω) were recorded using FeCo2P. Aside from the previously discussed merits of hollow structures for catalytic applications, FeCo2P performed better than the monometallic phosphides (Fe2P and Co2P) due to the synergism between Fe3+ and Co2+ ions., Overall, this study confirms the improved OER kinetics upon the incorporation of Co. [152]. In another study by Song et al., hollow Fe-Co x P nanospheres were also produced through a self-templating process [153]. Herein, Co-glycerate solid nanospheres synthesized through a hydrothermal route were used as sacrificial templates. In contrast to the work of Wang et al. in which Co was introduced into the Fe-containing precursor, herein, Fe was incorporated into the material by reacting the Co-glycerate spheres with K3[Fe(CN)6]. This ion exchange reaction yielded CoFe PBA, which was then converted to hollow Fe-Co x P nanospheres (Fig. 6f) through phosphidation. Due to the synergism between Fe and Co, and the unique hollow structure of the catalyst, the calculated η decreased after Fe was incorporated into CoP. At 50 mA cm−2, the value of η of Fe-Co x P in 1.0 M KOH was only 345 mV, which was considerably lower than that of Co x P (446 mV). Post-OER XRD analysis showed that the peak intensities of Fe-Co x P decreased. Furthermore, XPS results confirmed the oxidation of Co2+ and Fe3+ ions and the decrease in the amount of P in the catalyst. These post-OER characterizations showed that the phosphide surface was oxidized, where crystalline Fe-Co x P catalyst was possibly converted to FeCo (oxy)hydroxides (Fig. 6g) owing to the leakage of PO4 3− ions into the electrolyte, (Fig. 6h and i) thus increasing activity. Considering this finding, Fe-Co3O4 nanospheres were prepared through the thermal annealing of the similar precursors used to produce the Fe-Co x P catalyst (CoFe PBA hollow nanospheres). Interestingly, the η required to achieve 50 mA cm−2 using the Fe-Co3O4 nanosphere catalysts (444 mV) was higher than that required using Fe-Co x P. The electrochemical results (Fig. 6j) of this work prove the superior activity of phosphides relative to their oxide counterparts, and the potential of templated methods to produce high-performance, hollow catalysts for OER [153]. Ding et al. also fabricated hollow Fe-doped CoP catalysts through a self-templated route [154]. With a change in the reagent for the synthesis of precursors, Ding et al. produced hollow Fe-doped CoP prisms in contrast to Song et al.’s hollow nanospheres. Sacrificial Co-glycerate nanosphere templates were prepared using Co(NO3)2 · 6H2O and glycerol, whereas the prism-like Co precursor was produced using polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP, MW ∼55000) and (CH3COO)2Co·4H2O. As a surfactant and capping agent, PVP promotes the anisotropic growth of materials [155], thereby producing one-dimensional structures, such as the Co prisms in this work. The hollow Fe-doped CoP catalyst registered a low value of η 10 (236 mV) in 1.0 M KOH solution. Furthermore, its low Tafel slope (32.9 mV dec−1) proved the fast OER kinetics on the catalyst surface. The results of the works of Song et al. and Ding et al. demonstrate that templated methods can be used to fabricate catalysts with different morphologies by simply altering the reagents used in the synthesis [154]. Altering the reagents used in the templated synthesis also yields bimetallic phosphide chemistries other than FeCoP. Kaneti et al. produced hierarchical hollow bimetallic phosphides based on Mn and Co [148]. Similar to the work of Song et al., MnCo phosphide with a distinct hollow yolk–shell morphology was synthesized using Co-glycerate spheres as sacrificial templates. However, instead of using K3[Fe(CN)6] during the ion exchange reaction, Kaneti et al. dispersed the Co glycerate spheres in an Mn(NO3)2 solution. Fig. 7 (a–f) show the evolution of the morphology of the Co-glycerate spheres with increasing reaction time in the 0.01 M Mn(NO3)2 solution. Initially, the Co-glycerate spheres with diameters ranging from 500–800 nm exhibited smooth surfaces. After 2 h of reaction with the Mn precursor, the morphology gradually changed from solid spheres (Fig. 7a) to nanosheet-assembled spheres (Fig. 7b). With increasing reaction time from 2 to 4 and 6 h, the proportion of the yolk-shell spheres considerably increased (Fig. 7c and d). Finally, at 16 (Fig. 7e) and 24 h (Fig. 7f), this yolk-shell morphology disappeared and was replaced by nanoplates and aggregated nanoplates. Considering these results, reaction times up to 6 h were effective in producing the hierarchical MnCo layered double hydroxide (LDH) yolk-shell spheres. Two important processes possibly occurred during the reaction of the Co glycerate spheres with the Mn precursor: Mn doping and formation of the LDH structure. The yolk–shell structure of the precursor was retained even after the phosphidation of the MnCo LDH at 350 °C for 2 h under an N2 gas environment using NaH2PO2 · H2O (Fig. 7g and h). From N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms, the calculated BET specific surface area and pore volume of the MnCo phosphide catalyst were 86.1 m2 g−1 and 0.34 cm3 g−1, respectively. XRD results revealed that the hierarchical hollow catalyst was partially crystalline. In terms of the OER performance as shown in Fig. 7(i and j), the MnCo phosphide yolk–shell catalyst registered η 10 = 330 mV in 1.0 M KOH. For comparison, the OER activities of hierarchical CoP spheres and yolk–shell MnCo oxide spheres were also evaluated; at the same current density, the corresponding values of η calculated for these materials were 410 and 480 mV, respectively. These results further support that bimetallic compositions can improve the OER activity of phosphides owing to synergistic effects, and that phosphide materials exhibit better OER performances than their oxide counterparts [148]. In addition to MnCo-based bimetallic phosphides, Li et al. successfully synthesized other bimetallic phosphide compositions through a templated route [156]. Hierarchical, hollow Co-based bimetallic phosphide nanocages (CoMP-HHPNCs, where M = Ni, Cu, Mn) were prepared by varying the composition of the metal center of a ZIF-67 nanopolyhedra (NPH) precursor. First, CoM bimetallic ZIF-67 NPH precursors were synthesized and then transformed into hierarchical hollow polyhedral nanocages (HHPNCs) through a solvothermal reaction. During the synthesis of HHPNCs, surface etching and reconstruction processes occurred, which resulted in the formation of the hierarchical structure with a well-defined polyhedral interior cavity. Finally, a phosphidation step at 300 °C was performed to produce the CoMP-HHPNC catalysts. The CoMP-HHPNC catalysts had hollow cavities defined by a hierarchical shell, which was composed of ultrathin nanosheets. Electrochemical measurements were performed using 1.0 M KOH. In general, CoMP-HHPNC catalysts exhibited better OER performances than those of CoP-HHPNC. For example, the value of η 10 required using CoNiP-HHPNC was 18 mV lower than that needed using CoP-HHPNC (Fig. 7k). CoNiP-HHPNC also performed better than IrO2 and RuO2, which, at the same current density, registered η = 388 and 366 mV, respectively. In terms of the reaction kinetics, OER occurred more favorably on the surfaces of the bimetallic CoMP-HHPNC catalysts than on that of CoP-HHNC. The Tafel slope decreased in the order: 91 mV dec−1 (CoP-HHPNC) > 88 mV dec−1 (CoNiP-HHPNC) > 85 mV dec−1 (CoMnP-HHPNC). The better performance of the heteroatom-doped CoMP-HHPNC catalysts than that of the monometallic phosphide can be attributed to its hierarchical structure and higher conductivity. To better understand the rationale behind the activity enhancement after heteroatom doping, spin polarization DFT calculations were performed to determine OER activity descriptors: *OH, *O, and *OOH adsorption energies. CoP and Ni-doped CoP (CoNiP) surfaces were simulated. From the free energy diagram in Fig. 7(l) the rate-determining step was identified as the formation of the OOH* intermediate ( O ∗ + H 2 O → O O H ∗ + H + + e - ) .
