Comparing the energetics of this reaction step on the two surfaces reveals that Ni-doping altered the binding energy of CoP. The Ni dopant tuned the electronic structure of CoP, thereby optimizing the binding energies of the catalyst surface towards the OER intermediates [156]. Templated methods also prove useful for the preparation of hollow, trimetallic catalysts. Wang et al. synthesized hollow NiCoFe nanoboxes through an interface-induced contraction of Fe-PBA [138]. The fabrication of hollow TMPs through the direct phosphidation of precursors remain challenging. In [138], Ni3[Co[CN]6]2 and Fe3[Fe[CN]6]2 were initially used as precursors or templates to form NiCo PBA core–shell. Owing to the similar crystal structures of the two PBA-based precursors (i.e., matching lattice parameters), Fe PBA grew easily on the surface of the Ni3[Co[CN]6]2 nanoboxes. As the growth of Fe PBA on Ni3[Co[CN]6]2 continued, the desired NiCo@Fe PBA core–shell with similar crystal structure and morphology as those of the seed NiCo PBA was produced. A phosphidation step using NaH2PO2 with N2 gas purging then converted the NiCo@Fe PBA core–shell to hollow NiCoFeP catalysts (Fig. 7m). For comparison, bimetallic NiCoP NBs (Fig. 7n) were also prepared through the phosphidation of NiCo PBAs. Structural analyses through XRD revealed that for the bimetallic phosphide, Co was possibly incorporated into Ni2P forming amorphous Co oxyphosphide phases (Fig. 7o). Similarly, for the trimetallic NiCoFeP, no peaks were recorded corresponding to an FeP phase, indicating that Fe was incorporated into the Ni2P or that amorphous Fe oxyphosphides were produced. Through the interface-induced contraction of the NiCo@Fe PBA precursors during phosphidation, hollow NiCoFeP NBs with large, regular interior spaces were produced. Meanwhile, the hollow NiCoP NBs exhibited smaller and irregular interior spaces. Furthermore, the average edge length of the trimetallic NiCoFeP NBs was higher than that of the bimetallic NiCoP NBs. Interestingly, scanning transmission electron microscopy elemental maps after phosphidation report the presence of C, whereas XPS revealed the N-doping of the C matrix in the catalyst, implying the synthesis of a hybrid material composed of NiCoFeP and N-doped C. The OER activities of the hollow NiCoP and NiCoFeP NBs were evaluated in 1.0 M KOH (Fig. 7p). A commercially available RuO2 catalyst was also tested for comparison. The value of η at 20 mA cm−2 decreased in this order: 381 mV (RuO2) > 350 mV (hollow NiCoP NBs) > 277 mV (hollow NiCoFeP NBs). Moreover, the lowest Tafel slope (85.62 mV dec−1) was recorded on the hollow NiCoFeP catalyst. Among the samples tested, the hollow NiCoFeP exhibited the best OER performance considering that it has superior charge transfer characteristics from Fe doping of NiCo and the largest ECSA that provided more active sites for OER. Moreover, XPS studies conducted after post OER chronoamperometric test revealed that Fe doping can effectively increase the valence states of Ni and Co species in the catalyst, optimizing the oxygen and hydroxyl adsorption energies and in turn, facilitating OER. XPS studies also confirmed that the catalyst was oxidized during OER, forming (oxy)hydroxides. [138] The produced Fe-doped (oxy)hydroxide from the NiCoFeP pre-catalysts was possibly the active material for OER. This finding agrees well with the results of the work of Liu et al. on the OER activity of trimetallic CoNiFeP nanospindles synthesized through ion exchange and phosphidation method [157]. Aside from heteroatom doping, the construction of heterojunctions in hybrid, composite materials can also improve the OER performance of catalysts. Heterojunctions enhance the reaction kinetics by strengthening interactions between the interfaces and increase the active sites through the tuning of the catalyst porous channels [158]. Considering this, Yan et al. prepared a hollow CoP4/FeP4 composite catalyst through a templated synthesis method using CoFe PBA cube precursors [159]. For comparison, CoP4 and FeP4 catalysts were also prepared. CoP4, FeP4, and CoP4/FeP4 composite exhibited low degrees of crystallinity owing to the etching of the PBA-based precursors during the phosphidation at 400 °C using NaH2PO2 · H2O. CoP4 exhibited a uniform and solid cubic morphology with an approximate average size of 500 nm. FeP4 exhibited an irregular spherical morphology with a hollow cavity. The CoP4/FeP4 composite was composed of hollow nanocubes with surfaces evidently composed of pores. These morphological characteristics suggest that the introduction of Fe3+ ions affected the direction and increased the rate of internal etching, which resulted in the formation of a hollow hybrid catalyst. The position of the Co3+ peak in the XPS spectrum of the CoP4/FeP4 composite shifted toward higher binding energies relative to its position in the spectrum of CoP4, revealing that the Fe3+ ions affected the electronic distribution in the CoP4/FeP4. Meanwhile, the presence of Co shifted the binding energy of the Fe–P bond. At the same time, the P 2p signal in the XPS spectrum of the composite shifted to lower binding energies. These XPS findings imply that the metal electron density transferred around P. Electrochemical measurements using CoP4, FeP4, and CoP4/FeP4 were recorded in 1.0 M KOH. The value of η 10 using CoP4/FeP4 was 270 mV, which was the lowest among those of the samples tested and the commercial IrO2 catalyst (340 mV). Tafel analysis also revealed that the OER kinetics was more favorable on the CoP4/FeP4 catalyst surface (42.4 mV dec−1). Additionally, CoP4/FeP4 exhibited the lowest charge transfer resistance among the samples, implying the efficient ion/electron transport characteristics of the composite catalyst. These findings demonstrate the improvement of the reaction kinetics owing to the electron transport channels produced at the heterojunctions of hybrid composite catalysts. The catalytic activity of the CoP4/FeP4 towards HER was also evaluated. At 10 mA cm−2, the η registered by the composite was as low as 265 mV. The corresponding Tafel slope was 95.9 mV dec−1, indicating the Volmer process as the rate-determining step. An electrolytic cell was then constructed using the CoP4/FeP4 composite as both the anode and cathode. The cell potential required to reach 10 mA cm−2 was 1.74, lower than that of a Pt/C || IrO2 cell. In addition to this, the CoP4/FeP4 cell exhibited excellent stability even after 30 h of operation, confirming further the suitability of the composite catalyst prepared through templated synthesis as an electrode for practical applications [159]. Overall, hierarchical hollow nanostructures can be achieved mostly with the use of PBA templates. By varying the aging time and the type and identity of precursors during the synthesis of the PBA template, different catalyst shapes with hollow centers and promising OER activities can be produced. Multimetal doping and heterostructure engineering have also been proven to further improve the activity of hollow nanostructures. 3.2 Hierarchical porous catalysts Templated methods can also be employed to produce catalyst morphologies and architectures other than hollow particles. For example, hierarchical (meso- or nano-) porous structures have been achieved using different templated routes with different hard, soft, or sacrificial templates. For example, Li et. al prepared porous CoP NPs (Fig. 8 a) through a facile method using polystyrene (PS) spheres as templates and ZIF-67 as Co source [160]. Cobalt salt and 2-methylimidazole were introduced into a dispersion of PS spheres in methanol, thereby forming PS@ZIF-67 precursor. This precursor was heat treated at 350 °C in air for 2 h and then phosphidized at different temperatures using NaH2PO2 with N2 purging. The synthesized CoP catalyst exhibited a monodisperse and porous morphology. Owing to the porous structure, CoP NPs exhibited good OER activity with η 10 = 320 mV in 1.0 M KOH (Fig. 8b). In another study, Mei et al. produced an ordered mesoporous CoP catalyst through a hard-templating method using SBA-15 [161]. Similar to the work of Li et al., mesoporous Co3O4 (Fig. 8c) was prepared first and then phosphidized to obtain the desired CoP catalyst (Fig. 8d). The ordered mesoporous CoP registered η 10 = 300 mV and had steeper LSV curves and Tafel slopes than its bulk counterpart (Fig. 8e and f). As can be observed in the two previously discussed studies, hierarchical porous TMPs are often produced through the post-phosphidation of nanostructured metal oxides, which can contribute to environmental pollution and reduce the porosity of the products. Simpler and more effective routes for the synthesis of hierarchical porous TMP-based catalysts are thus sought after. Zhang et al. reported a facile self-templating strategy using red phosphorus as a template for the synthesis of a Ni12P5 OER electrocatalyst (Fig. 8g). The pore size distribution of the TMP product was tuned by varying the rate of the diffusion of Ni2+ ions and decomposition of the red phosphorus source through the addition of ionic liquids during the wet chemical synthesis [162]. Ni12P5 (Fig. 8h and i) exhibited large specific surface area (206.8 m2g−1) and pore volume (0.7145 cm3 g−1 nm−1), which conferred the catalyst with excellent OER properties (Fig. 8j and k), registering an η and Tafel slope equal to 246 mV and 46 mV dec−1, respectively. The result of the study suggests the possible application of ionic liquids as controlling agents for the templated synthesis of highly active and stable porous TMP catalysts for OER. 3.3 Flower-like OER catalysts Templated methods can also produce flower-like morphologies. Cheng et al. synthesized flower-like carbon-doped NiP (NiP/C) through the calcination of a hydrothermally synthesized nickel phenyl phosphonate template (Fig. 9 a) [163]. The phenyl phosphonic acid (PPA) ligand of the template served as the P source. In addition, PPA also decomposed to C during the heat treatment, thereby doping the NiP catalyst. The flower-like NiP/C catalyst registered an η 10 = 290 mV in 1.0 M KOH. This study demonstrated the good affinity of various metal ions with organic phosphonic acids. Thus, the facile approach utilized in the current work can be extended to the preparation of other carbon-doped TMPs with varying structures and properties. In another study, Xiao et al. also produced 3D flower-like structures based on Fe2P–NiCoP using MOF (MIL-88A) and LDH (NiCo LDH) dual precursors (templates) [164]. Initially, Ni and Co sources were introduced into MIL-88A spindles through hydrothermal method, forming a MIL–NiCoLDH intermediate. Through a low temperature phosphidation step, the intermediate was transformed into the desired Fe2P–NiCoP flowers. (Fig. 9b) The value of η required to reach 50 mA cm−2 in 1.0 M KOH solution was only 260 mV. (Fig. 9c) The Fe2P–NiCoP flowers also performed well in direct electrolysis, registering a low η of 278 mV to reach the same current density. 3.4 Ultrathin nanosheets Pan et al. reported the possibility of producing ultrathin Co2P nanosheets through a templated route using LiCl salt as the template [165]. The synthesis of the Co2P nanosheets (Fig. 10 a) involved three steps: mixing of the hydrothermally synthesized Co3O4 precursor with LiCl and NaH2PO2, low temperature phosphidation, and dissolution of the salt with the re-assembly of the nanosheets into restacked films. Inorganic salts lack catalytic activities but are employed to produce 2D layered structures (Fig. 10b and c). In this work, LiCl served not only as the template but also as a phase transfer agent. With increasing LiCl concentration, the intensity of the XRD peak corresponding to the CoP phase decreased while the XRD peak indexed to Co2P increased, implying the phase shift from CoP to Co2P. Interestingly, Co2P can also be produced through the phosphidation of the precursor at higher temperatures (300–600 °C) even without LiCl. This suggests that LiCl reduced the activation energy of the CoP–Co2P phase transformation. The overpotential recorded using the CoP nanosheets was 280 mV (Fig. 10d and e). At a Faradaic efficiency > 90%, the CoP nanosheets were able to catalyze OER at η 10 = 320 mV. In conclusion to this section, templated methods can be used to prepare TMP-based OER catalysts with different morphologies (hollow, hierarchical 3D structures, 2D structures, and porous (1D and 2D) morphologies), and compositions (mono-, bi-, and tri-metallic TMPs) by varying the templates (and precursors) used. Synthesis parameters, such as phosphidation duration, phosphidation temperature, and phosphorus source concentration, can also change the resulting morphology. This opens a lot of possibilities for the design and development of alternative OER catalysts with high activities and excellent stability. However, DHBT synthesis and other simpler techniques involving fewer complex templates are yet to be explored for the production of OER catalysts with porous and desirable morphologies and promising electrochemical performance. 4 Conclusions and perspective In summary, templated routes prove to be effective for the synthesis of transition metal phosphide (TMP)-based OER and HER catalysts. TMPs are regarded as one of the promising alternative electrocatalysts for OER and HER owing to their comparable activity to those of the noble metal catalysts and far better stability in alkaline environments. Templated routes allow the straightforward synthesis of TMPs with well-defined and precise morphologies (hollow and porous nanostructures), features that are often desired for catalytic materials. Nonetheless, the following perspectives (Scheme 2 ) might be considered to further improve the performance of TMPs as electrocatalytic materials for practical water electrolyzer applications. 4.1 Improvement of the activity and stability of TMPs towards OER and HER The poor electrical conductivity and high adsorption energies of the reaction intermediates on the surface of TMPs limit their large-scale application as electrode materials. As such, several strategies have been employed to improve the activity of TMPs; these include heteroatom doping, vacancy defect introduction, heterostructure and morphology engineering, and amorphization [166]. As previously discussed, templated synthesis routes, which often yield hollow and porous structures, prove to be useful in defect introduction, and heterostructure and morphology engineering. The most active TMP-based HER catalyst produced through templated synthesis registered even better activities than those of TMP electrodes prepared through other morphologies. However, more extensive studies on improving the OER activities of TMPs should be conducted. For the catalysts synthesized through templated methods alone, the lowest value of η 10 is still high at 246 mV [162]. As such, future work on OER catalysis may focus on combining two or more activity enhancement strategies to boost the performance of TMPs. The OER activity of TMPs in a wide array of pH conditions, i.e., in different electrolyte solutions, should also be evaluated. As an auxiliary strategy, HER has been coupled with other energy-efficient reactions, such as urea oxidation, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural oxidation, to decrease the value of η and improve the overall water-splitting efficiency [166]. In addition to activity, the stability of catalysts is an equally important criterion. For TMP-based catalysts, the most aggressive durability tests conducted thus far were performed at 80 mA cm−2 for 50 h and 100 mA cm−2 for 12 h [166]. However, for industrial-scale applications, electrode materials must exhibit excellent durability even under higher current densities for longer periods. Therefore, future work should focus on high-current density electrolysis studies using TMP-based electrodes. As an initial step for this perspective, standardized stability testing protocols must also be established to facilitate the comparison of results among different studies. 4.2 Design of more cost efficient and environmentally benign templated methods for the synthesis of porous TMP catalysts Hard-templated methods using SiO2 and AAO yield catalysts with highly tunable morphology and porosity. However, these synthesis routes require an additional template removal step, which further adds to the costs of the catalyst synthesis. To circumvent these disadvantages, soft templates, which are commonly morphology-directing surfactants and polymers, are used in lieu of hard templates. For this method, further studies on the effects of modifying agents (ionic liquids and surfactants), on the morphology, activity, and stability of catalysts should be conducted to develop high-performance materials. While they do not require the removal of templates, soft templating synthesis methods use surfactants, which can also be environmentally polluting. Therefore, templated synthesis routes that yield catalysts with uniform porosity without requiring the use of environmentally polluting surfactants and the additional template removal step must be developed. For this direction, dynamic H2 bubble template (DHBT) method shows immense potential. The use of H2 bubbles as the template during electrodeposition is a facile method to produce catalysts with hierarchical porosity. However, pore size control is yet to be studied for DHBT. Controlling the porosity requires the control of gas bubble size, which can be further explored by varying concentration ratios of metal and phosphide precursors and surfactants. Efforts in using templates should also be extended to its application in the synthesis of electrocatalyst materials for OER, not just for HER. Such endeavors can potentially redirect upscale production of bifunctional catalysts for water electrolysis from complex to simple synthesis methods. 4.3 Analysis of the reaction mechanism through advanced material characterization techniques and theoretical calculations Advanced material characterization techniques, such as in situ and operando measurements, and computational techniques, such as density functional theory (DFT) calculations, can be performed alongside the optimization of synthesis conditions to produce TMP-based OER and HER catalysts with the desired properties. TMPs have been identified to undergo surface reconstruction processes owing to the dynamic nature of the electrolysis reaction. As such, studying the underlying reaction mechanism is highly beneficial for the design of TMP-based electrocatalysts. However, conventional ex situ material characterization techniques cannot yield information about the changes in the surface chemistry, morphology, and defect concentration of the catalysts during cycling. For this reason, advanced in situ and operando material characterization techniques, such as in situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, in situ Raman spectroscopy, operando X-ray absorption spectroscopy, and identical location SEM and TEM, should be included in future works. Apart from the information discussed above, these advanced techniques also give information on the true active material responsible for the recorded electrocatalytic response. Once the true catalyst is identified, DFT calculations may be performed to determine the real active sites in the catalyst. Future DFT works may focus on taking into consideration the dynamic surface restructuring of TMP catalysts during cycling. By doing these, more accurate theoretical models that reveal the underlying structure–property relationships of catalysts can be drawn. Overall, the discussion in this paper on the most recent advances in the synthesis of TMP-based catalysts using templated methods, as well as the comprehensive review of the structure–property–performance of these OER and HER catalysts, may serve as a guide for the design and development of next-generation electrodes for electrochemical water splitting. Rose AnneAcedera is a Research Fellow III at the Laboratory of Electrochemical Engineering, Department of Chemical Engineering, University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman. She is currently taking a Ph.D. in Energy Engineering at UP Diliman, where she also received her B. Sc. in Materials Engineering (2017) and M. Sc. in Energy Engineering (2020). Her primary research interests include developing materials for energy storage applications. Alicia Theresse Dumlao received her B. Sc. in Chemical Engineering (2020) from the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman. Currently, she is taking her M. Sc. in Energy Engineering and working as a Research Fellow in the Laboratory of Electrochemical Engineering, Department of Chemical Engineering, UP Diliman. Her research interests lie in renewable energy systems and computational and experimental methods for electrocatalyst synthesis and characterization. DJ Donn Matienzo earned his master's degree in 2017 from the Università di Bologna and the Universitat de Barcelona. At the University of Chemistry and Technology in Prague, he earned his Ph.D. in Chemistry and Chemical technology (2021). He has worked in a variety of industries, including oil and gas, environmental compliance, and electrolyzer systems. He is a postdoctoral researcher at the University of the Philippines, an entrepreneurial lead at the Technological Institute of the Philippines, and the Chief Commercial Officer for a battery startup in the Philippines. Maricor Divinagracia received her Ph.D. in Energy Engineering (2022) at the University of the Philippines Diliman, where she also received her B. Sc. in Materials Engineering (2012) and M. Sc. in Energy Engineering (2016). She is currently a postdoctoral researcher at UP Diliman and the Electrochemistry R&D Division Head for a battery startup company in the Philippines. Her research is focused on developing materials for battery and fuel cell technologies. Julie Anne del Rosario Paraggua is an Associate Professor at the Department of Chemical Engineering, University of the Philippines Diliman. She received her Ph.D. in Chemical Engineering (2019) and M. Sc. in Environmental Science and Engineering (2013) from UP Diliman and Gwangju Institute of Science and Technology, respectively. She is a co-founder of the Laboratory of Electrochemical Engineering in which she works on research focusing on developing energy storage and conversion technologies, synthesis and characterization of electrodes, electrolytes, and electrocatalysts for batteries, electrolyzers, and fuel cells. Po-Ya Abel Chuang is an Associate Professor at the University of California, Merced. He earned his M. Sc. in Aerospace Engineering (1997) from the National Cheng Kung University and Ph.D. in Mechanical Engineering (2003) from Penn State University. Prof. Chuang went on to get his executive MBA degree from the Rochester Institute of Technology in 2009. Prof. Chuang's research interests primarily lie in the field of mechanical engineering, with a specific focus on energy conversion and thermal management systems. With his academic background and his extensive experience in the industry, he has various research projects and approved patents concerning fuel cells and water electrolyzer materials and technologies to his name. Joey D. Ocon is a Full Professor and the Co-founding Head of the Laboratory of Electrochemical Engineering of the University of the Philippines Diliman. A former Chair of the UP Department of Chemical Engineering, he has BS (2008) and MS (2011) in Chemical Engineering degrees from the same university and a Ph.D. in Environmental Science and Engineering (2015) degree from Gwangju Institute of Science and Technology South Korea. He is a recognized national expert on batteries, fuel cells, electrochemical technologies, energy systems, and off-grid electrification and has led many R&D projects from atomic-scale to energy systems research. He is an energy practice consultant in several organizations, including power companies and The World Bank. Prof. Ocon is also a Co-founder and Chief Science Officer of the battery technology start-up Nascent Battery Solutions Technologies.

coredata.dc:description: Transition metal phosphides (TMPs) have been regarded as alternative hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) catalysts owing to their comparable activity to those of noble metal-based catalysts. TMPs have been produced in various morphologies, including hollow and porous nanostructures, which are features deemed desirable for electrocatalytic materials. Templated synthesis routes are often responsible for such morphologies. This paper reviews the latest advances and existing challenges in the synthesis of TMP-based OER and HER catalysts through templated methods. A comprehensive review of the structure–property–performance of TMP-based HER and OER catalysts prepared using different templates is presented. The discussion proceeds according to application, first by HER and further divided among the types of templates used—from hard templates, sacrificial templates, and soft templates to the emerging dynamic hydrogen bubble template. OER catalysts are then reviewed and grouped according to their morphology. Finally, prospective research directions for the synthesis of hollow and porous TMP-based catalysts, such as improvements on both activity and stability of TMPs, design of environmentally benign templates and processes, and analysis of the reaction mechanism through advanced material characterization techniques and theoretical calculations, are suggested.
